Name: n-Heptadecane
Description: Heptadecane is a straight-chain alkane with 17 carbon atoms. It is a component of essential oils from plants like Opuntia littoralis and Annona squamosa. It has a role as a plant metabolite and a volatile oil component.

plant_concentrations.References: (1) EMBL-EBI; Heptadecane. Cambridgeshire, UK: European Molecular Biology Laboratory. European Bioinformatics Institute (EMBL-EBI). Available from, as of Jan 17, 2017: https://www.ebi.ac.uk/ebisearch/
plant_concentrations.Value: Heptadecane is a component of essential oils like Opuntia littoralis and Annona squamosa(1).

fish_seafood_concentrations.References: (1) Cha YJ, Cadwallader KR; J Food Sci 60: 19-24 (1995) (2) Al-Hassan JM et al; Bull Environ Contam Toxicol 65: 646-53 (2000) (3) Al-Hassan JM et al; Bull Environ Contam Toxicol 66: 646-52 (2001) (4) Durrani S, Siddiqui,SA; Marine Pollut Bulletin 21: 397-99 (1990)
fish_seafood_concentrations.Value: Mean concentrations for heptadecane of 2080, 2520, and 192 ng/g were determined in the volatile component of Korean salt-fermented fish and shrimp pastes from a Korean market that were made from anchovy, hair tail viscera, and shrimp, respectively(1). Barnacle samples collected from five locations in the Arabian Gulf had concentrations of heptadecane ranging from trace to 760 ng/g(2). Catfish samples collected from seven locations in the Arabian Gulf had concentrations of heptadecane ranging from <0.1 to 218 ng/g(3). Heptadecane was detected in the sediments from the coastal waters of Karachi but not detected in oyster samples (Crassostrea rivularis and Perna virdis) or fish samples Mugil sp and Acanthopagurus sp collected from the same areas(4).

sediment_soil_concentrations.References: (1) Rushdi AI et al; Archives of Environ Contam Toxicol 49: 457-470 (2005)
sediment_soil_concentrations.Value: SOIL: During the winter of 2002, soil and sand samples from six locations in the Riyadh metropolitan area of Saudi Arabia were examined for extractable organic matter. Heptadecane was detected at relative concentrations between 0.25 to 2.11% (of total extractable organic matter) at three of six locations(1).
